file_content.text: Commander Madine's been waiting on the comm for your return. I'll patch him through now.
I'm glad you're back. We've got no time to waste. Doctor Meln and Doctor Ortis have created the Barrager spike.
It's hacked together from memory, so they can't guarantee anything. We really could have used their research.
It's hard to ignore a prison full of innocent people.
The prisoners needed me.
Would you rather have the research than the doctors?
Look at it another way.
No, but I see your point.
Civilians were in danger, Commander.
I didn't have a choice.
You eliminated most of the prison staff. Once we had the Barrager, they wouldn't have waited long for a rescue.
Spit and bailing wire usually does the trick.
I'm sure it'll work out fine.
Until it breaks. But I'm sure that's never happened to you.
The decision's been made.
The decision's been made.
The decision's been made.
So, saving people's lives isn't really a priority for you.
You've got a one-track mind.
I'm here to win a war for the Republic.
I just hope the spike works. The Barrager could prevent another Telos or Taris forever. The Republic must get control of it.
It's foolproof. They've promised complete control. It's fortunate we had access to their research.
If the research makes the road ahead easier, I'm glad I could save it.
I'm pleased to hear it.
The less question marks on an operation, the better.
It was worth the effort.
The Barrager's the big picture here.
My eye's on the prize.
I'm glad to hear you say that. Getting control of the Barrager is the key to Republic victory.
What happens now?
You don't plan on leaving those prisoners in the Gorinth Brig, do you?
You're not finished here.
If we can get control of the Barrager, the entire planet will be free.
Our plan's hit a small snag. We've been unable to get in touch with Doctor Carsiri, the informant who started all this.
You suspect the Empire discovered him?
You think he got caught?
Doctor Carsiri's brilliant, but I doubt he has much experience covering his tracks.
For all we know, he may just be unable to get away.
Let's not worry just yet.
You may be right, but it never hurts to prepare for the worst.
Can we get anyone inside to check up on him?
He might need our help.
We tried, but none of my agents can get close enough.
You don't think he turned snitch, do you?
Maybe he betrayed us.
If he was any other man, I might. But he's much too eager to be a hero.
Forget him. We've got the Barrager's designers.
He's useless now anyway.
Doctor Meln and Doctor Ortis have been Imperial prisoners for months. Only Doctor Carsiri knows how to get inside the Barrager laboratory.
The Empire's massing their troops at the Balmorran Arms Factory. It's a battle from here on in.
We've got to move forward, with or without Doctor Carsiri. My technician Lem Karner's been working on locating the Barrager. He's waiting for you at the Sundari Outpost.
Tell Lem I'll be there as soon as possible.
I'll head there next.
I'm still worried.
If it's any consolation, you're not the only one.
Can Lem find the Barrager without Doctor Carsiri?
Is Lem up to this?
Lem once detected an Imperial destroyer after it made the jump to hyperspace. If he can't find it, it doesn't exist.
I'll keep trying to contact Doctor Carsiri. I'll let you know if I hear from him. Madine out.
Imperial movements have picked up speed. You've gotten a little too close for comfort.
Word on all Imperial channels is that a Republic army invaded the Gorinth Brig. Looks like you embarrassed them enough to lie.
Did Doctor Meln and Doctor Ortis make it back?
Where are the doctors?
They chose their fate.
They chose their fate.
If anyone deserved it, it's Lieutenant Vekarr and the Extractors. A lot of Balmorrans will sleep easier tonight.
Well, whatever stims you're taking, keep it up--Balmorra's not free yet.
I put Doctor Meln and Doctor Ortis on a shuttle to Bugtown. They were chattering about the Barrager all the way up the gangplank.
You'll be the first Republic agent inside the Gorinth Brig. Let's hope you're the first to come out.
The Gorinth Brig is run by Lieutenant Vekarr. He's the worst kind of Imperial--the kind that thinks he makes the galaxy a better place.
If he already thinks that, he might be willing to make it true.
Maybe he'll see reason.
A man who's had families slaughtered just to keep his prisoners in line? I doubt it.
Any other defenses?
Lieutenant Vekarr's going to die. Same as the rest.
Then he gets no mercy.
You'll get a personal thank you from me if that happens. He's terrorized this area long enough.
Lieutenant Vekarr's not alone. He commands an elite unit of guards known as the Extractors--nastiest, cold-hearted drones in the Empire.
They'll still get a chance to surrender, even if they won't take it.
Even drones deserve mercy.
The first shot won't come from me.
Our elites are different.
Sometimes all a busted hyperdrive needs is a good kick.
Nothing I can't handle.
You're exaggerating.
Ask the prisoners if you don't believe me. Better yet, free the prisoners.
The shuttle will be ready and waiting for Doctor Meln and Doctor Ortis. Good luck.
I've got the access key to the Gorinth Brig.
Looks like your access key and mine match up perfectly. That should be all you need to get inside, but once you're in, be careful.
You worry about those access keys. I've got the rest.
So you're my contact. Wes Durga, Republic scout.
I'm glad the Republic's finally taking an interest in the Gorinth Brig. Too many Balmorran civilians have died in there.
Madine didn't say that.
The locals are tight-lipped, probably because they're afraid of ending up there themselves. I don't blame them.
Commander Madine said you knew how to get inside.
I need your intel to help.
War is a harsh place.
Prisoners are tortured, interrogated, convinced they're guilty of crimes that never happened. You and me, we don't know what bad is.
You'll need two access keys to get inside the Gorinth Brig. I've got one. You'll have to pry the other out of an Imperial officer's cold, dead hands.
Remind me never to join the Empire.
Word is there's also a spare set at each officer's comm station, but sneaking around seems like more courtesy than the Imperials are worth.
I'll make arrangements to shuttle your scientists out of here. Get that second access key and get back quick.
I have to keep my eyes open. The Republic relies on me.
I see Imperials, I kill them.
I see Imperials, I kill them.
I see Imperials, I kill them.
Either way, I can handle it.
I'll hang on to the other key, just in case.
I prefer a straight fight, but sometimes I surprise myself.
We'll see what happens.
They're not worth the ammo either.
Killing them is no better.
Enough Imperials will likely die in the Gorinth Brig.
I won't kill if I can help it.
I could hear the firefight from here. But as long as all the Imperials are dead, I'm not complaining.
How you did it without taking down an officer is one for the history books. I didn't hear a thing about it.
What should we do?
Yeah, I'm pretty good.
Yeah, I'm pretty good.
I can be nasty too.
Is that how you got yours?
Mine was dead when I got to him. You'll have to get yours the hard way.
I'd rather not kill anyone.
You want to ask nicely for them, be my guest. I'll laugh at you from here.
Sounds like my kind of fun.
